 "I don't know you, honey. Have to be sure you can handle this." 

"No sweat. House rules are fine. Do what you gotta do." 

She returned with a more relaxed countenance and handed my card back to me. The sound of conversation and football games on the TVs returned to the room. I ordered their Paddy Melt and sipped on the dark rusty ambered brew. 

This joint was the diviest of taverns. Operated by Darby since 1998, and housed in a large building considerably older than that, it had been decades since it was cleaned thoroughly. The underflooring was exposed in many places and the knotty pine paneling was grease and beer splattered.

 Almost Heaven. West Virginia. 

The grilled sandwich was pretty good with loads of sauteed onions and crunchy rye holding a half pound of burger and melted swiss. The ketchup was watery, but what the hey? It tasted good and was filling with a shovel of fries for an extra buck. 

I paid with a reasonable tip for Ms. D, and walked out into the cool bright late afternoon sunlight. The parking lot was as torn up as the barroom floor. There was a ragged trailer park out back that appeared to be in the same condition as everything else around there. 

As I found my way out of this strange wet and desolate area, I was amazed that this place was part of contemporary Bucks County, and not a piece of land that time forgot.

There is no Stella!

I don't know how to break it to you gently, so I'll just come right out and say it. There is no Stella @ Stella's House Blend Cafe. 

But, there is a Tiki (goddess) running the show, and she has the joint jumping. It was a capacity crowd at 10 am on Labor Day. The old 19th Century corner building in the heart of Sellersville, Pa, is as busy now as it ever was. The first floor occupied by this breakfast/lunch house has been brought back to life with TLC and a vision.  Have a good kitchen and they will come. They do, and they did.

I found a seat at the counter between two big fellas, and felt a moment of guilt being alone and able to skip the queue waiting for tables. It didn't last long. From my perch the kitchen was visible, and I could watch to servers at work. Teamwork!

My French Toast with Strawberries and Blueberries was made from multigrain bread as they were out of Texas Toast by the time I arrived.  No problem.  Done right, FT pleases me in almost any form.  This rendition was very good.  I also asked for the real Maple Syrup, a $1.50 extra, because there is little point to eating great FT with run of the mill pancake syrup.  The Maple enhances, while the sweet corn syrup used by Log Cabin and the like, diminishes the flavor of the dish.  

The plate arrived loaded with bread and berries.  Gorgeous!  The side of Bacon I requested well done, was precisely that.  Firm, crunchy and with a splash of Maple, a delicious complement to the main.  Everything tasted very fresh, and their local sourcing policy seemed to be working well.  Same with the java.  Local roaster makes awesome joe.  Strong. Savory. A touch of milk to take the edge off.  

Stella's House Blend Café would seem to be about the coffee, but that would deny the strength of the menu, and the skill in the kitchen.  Just about everything about this joint is fun and affirming.  

Hey, Tiki!  I really like what you've done with the place.  A wonderful place to end a beautiful September drive in the country.

Trenton, New Jersey, is the last of the state capitals to have a Starbucks.  After 400+ years of history, it has finally arrived.  And, from the look of the place, the Green Mermaid spared little expense in designing this java joint. It is large, bright and original.  Cut in a triangular shape at the corner of Front Street and South Warren Street, on the first floor of a State office building, the two outer walls are all glass, and both are lined with comfortable sitting areas for work and conversation.  The back walls are painted with colorful murals of famous cityscapes - including the famous Trenton Makes Bridge across the Mighty Delaware River to Pennsylvania. 

The coffee is standard Starbucks (not my favorite), but there is something to be said for consistency.  Their reliable snacks are present, and the service is friendly, knowledgeable and efficient. Everyone gets "TO GO" cups, even those hanging out, to save on losses. 

I enjoyed the fact that this beautiful facility was actually in this Sad Sack city, as much as I enjoyed my latte and slice of lemon pound cake.  I watched as people filtered in and out.  No one seemed to be taking the space for granted.  The gold balloons didn't let that happen. 

I allowed myself a moment of pride and gratification for this city that has been down so long that Starbucks is a very big win. Let's hope it is the beginning of a renaissance that has been awaited since Washington surprised the Hessians on a cold Christmas morn.

There is a simple reason almost all the reviews for The Dutch on S. 4th Street are 5 Star. They deserve every star they get! 

I am not a regular part of the weekend breakfast/brunch scene in Philly, but given a reason to be in the Pennsport neighborhood early on a Saturday morning, I willing partake of this lovely cottage industry.  The small corner shop is bright and airy, even on an overcast day.  Pale and deeper blues offset the whitewashed walls, giving the feel of happiness and cleanliness.  There are two levels.  Dining room in the front of the house with around 10 small wood top tables, and a step up in the rear with a traditional counter and semi-open kitchen.  The owners are very hands on, supervising, serving, cashiering and hosting.  The "Double Wilkum" hex suits the personality of this place. 

We walked in around 8:30 to a half full room.  We were shown to one of the small deuces toward the back of the dining area, and had a fresh large cup of java steaming my glasses in less than a minute.  The menu is short and sweet.  But, don't be misled by its list of offerings that look like any other hash house.  Hidden within the deceptively simply names are the creative energies of these "Dutchmen."  

My Huevos Rancheros was not very South of the Border, but certainly tipped their sombrero in homage to the venerable dish.  Rather than tortillas, upon a base of Corn Meal Waffle were placed a shiny Sunny Side Up Egg, melted Cheese,  Fresh Tomato Salsa, Guacamole, Black Beans and well grilled and pressed thick cut Bacon; covered in mild Hollandaise.  Pretty as a picture on the plate, the assemblage had a great taste, if not overwhelmingly Mexi heat.  I never thought of corn and waffles in the same breath, but it worked like a charm.  It held all the component parts together, and sent the meal in an unexpected direction.  

My companion's Ham & Eggs with 3 Over Easys, interestingly delicious Hash Browns, and thick sliced Marble Rye, was devoured with little offered to me to taste.  I did manage a couple of sly bites when she went to the WC, and understood why she was not in a particularly sharing mood.  

This neighborhood is gentrifying, but still maintains its authentic South Philly personality.  On a less muggy day, sitting at the sidewalk tables would be a nice way to watch this part of the world go by.

I know Johnny G's Famous Pizza on Brownsville Road, Trevose, PA, is supposed to be all about tomato pie, steak sammies and other Italian goodies, but my first visit ended up being all about their burgers. 

They said they were half pounders made from never frozen Angus beef, with assorted toppings and a side of fries for an extra buck fifty. Brioche style buns held them together and offered sturdy handholds for the heft of the large slider. I realized the risk from bypassing their signature dishes, but why all the menu space for burgers? Why the interesting combinations? 

I had the answers when the large plate with Mighty Mike Burger was placed before me by the pleasant server in training. The roll top shined like it had been polished. The edge of the beef was thick, with a tip of bacon peaking out on top of melted swiss cheese. My request for medium finish was honored precisely. 

And it was a great Burger! Hot, drip juicy, flavorful. Russian dressing adding a sweet creamy note. A joyful surprise first bite to last. Beautiful pink at heart, and true to its credo of never having seen the inside of a freezer.

Better than Guys, Shack, Smash, Robin and many others with catchy names; at about half the price. 

How do they keep this joint a secret?!

Covello's on South Broad Street, Trenton, has been at this location for thirty years. It's been at least twenty since the last time I walked in their front door. Now that I am working downtown again this old joint is back on my lunch rotation. 

It hadn't changed that much. Still a big room with many booths and counter service along a front wall. Still the standard Italian pizzeria with pies, calzones, hot & cold sandwiches, salads, pasta and platters. I ordered an eggplant parmesan sandy and picked my booth to await its preparation and delivery.

It was very, very good. 

Lightly breaded thin slices of nightshade, slightly crisp outside and soft within. Enough melted mozza to promote textural integrity, but not too much to swallow the intended star of the show. Fresh, basil sweet chunky sauce dolloped on top, and all of it housed in a really good Italian roll.  It was a foot long; cut in half. So much for $6.95!  I needed knife and fork to go after the heart of the sandwich, and then ate half the delicious bread toward the end, almost like dessert. Crusty, warm and flavored with everything it had held in its once molten valley. 

So assuring that Covello's hasn't missed a beat in all these years.

This health food and nutrition shop has been located at the same location for decades. Walking into this converted residential bungalow, I was overwhelmed by the floor to ceiling shelving packed with everything from vitamins to dry goods to frozen foods. The store has aged well, and has become as much a cultural museum, as a retail outlet designed to assist in maintaining health. 

We stopped in to purchase more supplements that had run out at home. A clerk who worked there approached with a welcoming smile and showed us where what we sought was resting on the highest shelf in the house. She climbed a stepstool to reach them. They had a sale going on, and the price was very fair. We bought two. 

I loved the old wooden built-ins housing the drygoods, granolas and nut mixes. They would look great in our kitchen (alas). I could see how the claustrophobic might be challenged by the stuffed to the gills nature of this tiny store. But, for me, it was a cozy room that instant relaxed me and captured my curiosity. 

Now that our usual health food shop has closed its doors, The Natural Foods Store may well become our regular stop for nutritional maintenance.

So, what's a "flexitarian?" 

I didn't know either until I sat at the counter in the Silver Diner, and had it explained for me in their elaborate menu. Apparently, when health consciousness is a priority, local sourcing predominates and the offerings change with the seasons, you have created a flexitarian restaurant. So, although its stainless steel & glass shell suggests a traditional Jersey diner experience awaits, in fact nothing could be further from the truth. This is a new age epicurian delight on par with the Turning Points of the world, without the pretense and only some of the accompanying cost. 

My Country Griddle breakfast (scrambled eggs, onion, green pepper, morning sausage, mushroom, potato and 2 tone melted cheddar) in a large bowl with fresh biscuit on top, was delicious and filling. The coffee was hot and strong, with a small pitcher of cold milk provided at my request (may have been from Amish cows). From my perch at the counter I could see into the kitchen where the white hats seemed to be having a good time. 

Even if you don't know anything about flexitarian kitchens, you can find your way to a very pleasurable meal @ Silver Diner. 

Nice going!

If mid 20th Century Archie & Veronica malt shops and Back to the Future big fin American road steel move your imagination, then Jem's Restaurant in East Norristown, PA, may be for you. 

What from the outside looks like another shopping center fast food luncheonette constrained by its surroundings to be a boring food dealer, is in fact a real trip down memory lane. The joint is a museum of cultural artifacts from the early days of television, with large posters of Rebel Without a Cause, James Dean, and Seven Year Itch, Marilyn Monroe. Perhaps that's why the room was full with retirees and people over the age of 70 (except for those of us needing to eat and run). This place is the original greasy spoon, for all the right reasons. 

The double "U" counter separated the kitchen from the dining room. My spinner faced the grill operated by two short order cooks who worked smoothly in tandem. I ordered coffee and Jem's Scramble with feta and rye toast. The full insulated carafe of java set in front of me was a nice touch. I listened to the repartee between customers and servers. It was familiar and entertaining. Most everyone seemed to be a regular. 

I noted the pile of chunk cut red bliss potatoes and metal tray of bacon on the grill. I watched eggs, pancakes, french toast and breakfast sandwiches being cooked and constructed as spatulas flew. I also saw that the grill was not scaped clean between orders, allowing residue from everything grilled there to build up and become part of the next dish. No judgement. Then, my small Scramble arrived, steaming in my face and fogging my glasses. Smelled awesome and looked like a gently beckoning glistening syren. 

It was delicious. The eggs held the sausage, onions, peppers and feta in a wet/warm embrace, allowing each forkful to hang together with all elements dancing on my tongue. There was also a hint of everything else that came before, making for a mysterious, yet very pleasant flavor. 

Maybe that is the house secret to success, or just how it accidentally became an amazing greasy spoon. Intentional or not, Jem's has a full house every morning, and is definitely doing something right.

Love Groucho or not, Duck Soup Cafe is a great place for breakfast and coffee. It is hard to find in Logan Square Shopping Center, but if you drive around back on the eastern side the rear door and sign are visible as the best way in. 

Started 35 years ago by the same family running it now, the place has an easy Americana coziness and knotty pine charm that makes for a relaxing environment. The menu is similarly built on kitchen classics, with one side for morning victuals, and the reverse, lunch. I was the second customer when I walked in around 9:20. I liked the country vibe and took a table in the front corner under the windows and across from the cashier counter and kitchen entrance.

Their french toast was constructed from a thin cut croissant, and included fresh cool sweet butter to melt, real grade A dark maple syrup and two bacon slices. It was all very good, as was the bottomless coffee mug. Service was beautifully provided by Michelle, daughter of the owner/chef of the house. They both seemed to know all their customers, but me, and came out to greet everyone and catch up of the daily New Hope gossip.

One of the benefits of Logan Square is that it is not downtown in tourist centric New Hope. Rather, this is for the locals, with real quality and reasonable prices.

One Up One Down Coffee is the new urban cafe on Cass Street, Trenton, that took the place of the previous occupant, the Trenton Coffee House. With a little spit and polish they have made the original Polish Falconer Club into an attractive reuse that is bright and comfortable, with lots of handworked wood bars and tables, block glass windows, and large coffee bean roaster where they control the production of excellent java. 

In addition to a broad caffeinated menu, they sell a few pastries - cookies, scones and brownies, as well as carrying bags and sacks with their logo on them. You can tell they are really just getting started, but have a marketing plan in keeping with the hard edged neighborhood where they ply their trade. Trenton State Prison is right down the street, where hard time takes on an altogether new meaning. 

I asked for Chai Latte, and it was handed to me minutes later in a large cup in saucer. It was well done and went down easy. They were kind enough to allow me to eat a bagel I had picked up earlier. I had intended to bring it to my office on South Broad, but when I drove by One Up One Down, I had a change of plans and wanted to take a little time on a chill Friday morning to enjoy a diversion. 

Spontaneity completely made my day, even if I wore my mask in and out to honor Covid Protocol.

There is little doubt that Rocco's is the best restaurant currently in Newtown. This may change as there are new kitchens opening up almost weekly in the community, but right now, this steakhouse has it going on full bore. 

I had dinner there with son and his girlfriend the other night. We sat in the glass enclosed porch that rings the first floor. The space is beautifully appointed in colonial style, and white table cloths and heavy stainless flatware. It is a pleasure to walk through the barroom and dining room to reach the porch. From that perch the Newtown bustle can be witnessed first hand. We were there to celebrate several occasions that had gone  unrecognized over the past 16 months due to Covid. We had much to be thankful for. 

Son o'mine loves his steak, and his N.Y Strip done medium was beyond excellent in texture and robust flavor. He cut me a piece knowing that this was not my normal diet, but that I was open to experiencing superior dishes. Yes, it was amazing, and it was easy to understand his attraction. I had to concentrate to appreciate everything that was going on in my mouth as I chewed and savored. His girlfriend went with a medium filet. It wasn't as juicy as the strip by observation, but she was clearly loving every bite of her medium round thick slab of beef. 

I went with the French Onion Soup and Prime Burger, knowing my diet couldn't handle a platter of solid beef. The soup qualified for possible the best of breed in a lifetime. It was rich, savory, onions, hearty beef stock, topped with french loaf under a thick layer of gruyere, seared to a near-blackened finish either in the oven or by blowtorch. The cheese had to be pierced to access the molten potage below, and to permit the superheated steam to escape. It was epic, and nearly a meal by itself.  Stupendous! 

After all this, the burger was a bit of a disappointment. True, it was a combination of ground beef, short rib and brisket, topped with onion, tomato, lettuce and melted provolone, in a brioche bun. But, flavor-wise it was a situation where more is less. I didn't get off on the mix of beef. It just didn't taste like a high end burger. I like short rib and brisket at BBQ joints, but prefer them separately, where each of their distinct attributes can be appreciated, and not muddled together. So, it was disappointing after the star quality of everything else. The fries were standard crispers. 

So, Rocco gets a less than perfect five stars here. Despite the burger, the rest of the experience was top notch, and the bar/dining area stunning In an understated way. On a less precipitous evening, eating outside would have been a legitimate option, but despite the umbrellas, we would have had to endure wet shoulders from the tropical storm brewing outside. 

No wonder Rocco's is booked solid every night. It is truly a first class night on the town.

Five Guys makes the best grease burgers! 

Grilled on steel that is seldom cleaned during hours of operation, the beef sizzles until well done, when it is lifted off the heat and placed on a bun already prepared with whatever accessories you want. Whatever else they do to the body, they are incredibly tasty and provide excellent lubrication to the alimentary canal. 

In addition, 5 Guys make great fries that far outclass their better known brothers. Their signature move is to toss extra fries in the brown paper bag after putting in the primary load carried in a paper cup. Excessive, but nicely so. Same goes for their shakes, which are also superior to the beef pucks. They are creamy, sweet cool ice cream splurges. Pricey, but the super caloric craving supercedes the doubtful overall nutritional value. 

So, it is an upside down meal if you think about it, but certainly a ton of fun on a bun. 

Unbeknownst to me, I had ordered online from the Five Guys on Lincoln Highway, but not the road running through Bucks County, A/K/A Route 1, but rather the one in Lancaster, PA., over 100 miles away. My bad. I wrongly assumed that their locations were in order of proximity to where I lived. Not so on their app, so the reference to Lincoln Highway led me astray. You know, I saw what I expected to see (Langhorne rather than the actual Lancaster) and impulsively jumped the gun. 

This is where Five Guys superhero Tyler stepped in to save the day. When the shop didn't have my order, he asked to see my phone and immediately knew what had happened. Not for the first time, he explained. He immediately reordered everything on the register and comped the charges, knowing I had already paid their sister store. They could correct this internally. 

Tyler's superpower - being supercool and knowing exactly what to do without making me feel like a bigger smacked ass than I already did. All this coolness made the enjoyment of my "special meal" almost a secondary consideration. 

Almost, but not quite, as it was digestible proof that some classy teenagers are ready to rule the world.

If you enjoy classic Italian cuisine with a touch of something more modern, set in an beautifully renovated house, La Strada is calling your name. 

Its main dining room is a large round room that may have been a solarium in a past life, but has become a space large enough for a dozen or more tables amply spaced and fully windowed to permit the world outside to come in. As this is the older part of town, you can see 18rh and 19th Century buildings that remind of the pre and post revolutionary history of the area. 

The menu has all the traditional dishes, some with a special flare away from what would be expected. For example, we ordered Calamari which came drizzled with a Thai Sweet Chili Sauce and Balsamic drip. All larger rings, it was a delicious surprise treat. Our Chicken Marsala and Francais were more classical, with two large breasts each atop Penne and wonderful reductions in Marsala Wine with fresh mushrooms and lightly dredged flour coat and  Lemon White Wine base, respectively. Tender enough to be cut with our forks. 

Service was a bit slow, but not bad for a romantic Sunday night. We regretted not bringing our own bottle to this BYOB house. 

Aside - All through the meal I had the feeling that this was a Roman room in the fine tradition of Trenton's Chambersburg neighborhood, which at one time had awesome Italian kitchens on every corner. They were classy and always full with locals manging to their hearts' content. Those days have turned to Spanish/Latino pleasures, but it's great to know that that Guilded Age can still be found if we look hard enough. In fact, the owners are from Trenton, and seemed pleasantly surprised to chat briefly about the old world, where I still have an office, and loads of memories.

La Strada is of that fine school.

Vinny G's sits at the corner of 4th & Broad in the lovely Delaware River town of Florence, NJ. For those of you who have never had the good fortune to visit this small burg in Burlington County, checking out its timeless charm is a great reason to make the trip, and Vinny's Bagel & Deli makes it even more worthwhile. This spot is one of the hidden places in the Garden State that will change your mind about the historic romanticism of Jersey. 

Yes. The bagels are very good, too. They are large, fresh, light and covered in your condiment of choice. The skin isn't as crisp as I prefer, but from first bite to last chew, it was a tasty delight. My Onion rounder with Veggie Cream Cheese spread, washed down with their House Blend coffee was satisfying and tasted of the love they put into it. 

Service was attentive and friendly. The woman who assisted me seemed genuinely happy to see me and had my bagel picked, sliced, smeared, wrapped, bagged and ready to go before I finished pouring my self-service java. 

I drove to the office along the river enjoying the bucolic setting on a mid April Spring day, anticipating that first bite ecstasy awaiting me. 

I was not disappointed.

Ota-Ya requires a bit of patience to find.  Sitting out back off Cambridge Lane in Newtown, it is easy to have never known that this place existed.  It is next door to Mamita's, the new Central American resto. If you don't know where that is, then you need to call ahead to speak with the very friendly owners who are accustomed to directing lost patrons.  

If you are familiar with the current state of Sushi/Japanese houses; this is not that.  It is an older space, without the front row knifemen flashing blades nor rice shapers. All that creative stuff is done in the back (kitchen).  What you see is the finished product brought to you by management or an on-the-ball server who knows everything about the menu, and will tell you what she/he thinks is de rigor for lunch or dinner.  The floor plan is rather small for a contemporary restaurant, reflecting that Ota-Ya has been slicing fish for a long time without the need for floorshows.  The aura is dark, the tables and chairs old, and the overall atmospherics close and subdued.  Whispering comes naturally.

But, in exchange for being the anti-Oishi in Ntown you get the best sushi.  Fresh, creative, aesthetic and self-assured.  If you love old Zato-Ichi movies, this is your place.  The blind swordsman sits quietly while the nasty Samurais' steel slice each other up defending their noble's honor. Finally, when the dominant villian and his henchman are about to kill the last innocent, Zato-Ichi excuses himself meekly, unsheathes his short sword, and dispatches the baddies while holding a baby in his free hand. 

 "...so sorry for the disturbance, young prince..."

Have whatever you want here.  It is all very good.  If raw fish is not for you, there is plenty of excellent Tempura, Teriyaki, Udon, Bentos, and Salads.  The owners are happy to chat with you if they have time, and if not crowded feel free to ask for a refill of the Green Tea and sit a while.

It is time to revisit my past reviews of House of Pho, and update my impressions and ranking for this ever improving Vietnamese restaurant.  

Returning for the first time in a few months, the first thing I noticed was the presence of booths along the front windows.  We sat there, and the additional privacy was felt immediately.  Great touch!  They also had moved the drink menu onto a table card for immediate perusal and quick ordering.  Smart move to save the time of waiting for the arrival of the menu.  We selected the Mango Smoothy and Coconut Tuoi, and had them at the table within minutes, and before we ordered the victuals. The Smoothie was sweet and creamy, just as I remembered it, and the Tuoi was a mild coconut infused water with thin Coconut shavings in the glass.  Mildly sweet and instantly refreshing.  

We ordered the Spring Roll app, Grilled Shrimp with Lemongrass Sauce, and a small Pho Gai (Chicken).  The Spring Roll was cool, crisp and so fresh, with extra large Shrimp seen through the translucent skins.  The Peanut Sauce had a bit of a spicy kick and complemented the sweet crispness of the roll.  The Grilled Shrimp were smaller than in the Roll, but numerous, and arrived nestled in a lettuce leaf.  The Lemongrass Sauce was an interesting taste, less dominant that its Thai sibling, but well used with the shrimp.  It was subtle and I really appreciate the interplay with the light BBQness of the Shrimp. Finally, the soup was Pho-n-tastic; hot broth with large slivers of Chicken Breast and Noodles. The flavor was superb.  This is a clear broth as opposed to the sometimes tawny opaque smoky flavor offered by other pho joints.  Of course, it came with a side plate loaded with sprouts, basil leaves, jalapeno slices and wedge of lime. The bowl was so full when I finished preparing it I had to press down gently with my spoon to suppress the garnish and allow some soup into my spoon. A slightly bigger bowl with the same amount of ingredients might have been a good idea to avoid spillage. Totally satisfying.

We finished with VN Coffee and Green Tea, so we could sit for a while longer and talk while we continued to enjoy the evening created by House of Pho.

This establishment has become first class.  It need offer no apology to sister shops in nearby urban centers.  In fact, I recently returned from Garden Grove, California, the Vietnamese capital in the USA, where I sampled a few Vietnamese delights.  None were any better than House of Pho, and some were considerably worse. 

5 Stars to House of Pho.  Great work, Fred and Victor!

OCTOBER 4, 2014 - The best places continue to evolve as they find their groove and have the courage to explore the outer limits.  House of Pho follows this tradition.  Their menu is broader as they are now offering special seafood dishes, no doubt putting a creative edge to a marketing survey to see where to go next. 

 The house remains clean and coolly inviting.  The staff seems to finally feel comfortable with the kitchen genius, and Fred and Victor reign serenely over their domain. Today's Jackfruit Smoothie was so good ($1. off) and my Com Thit Nuong tasty and full of Pork, Noodles and Spouts.  While I went in for the Pho, the alternatives overcame me, and I went with something new for me.  

Still a 5 Star experience.

JANUARY 5, 2015 - Stopped in last night for a Pho dinner and decided to try the Spicy Hot Wings in their Signature Sauce.  They were hot, crisp, peppery, sweet, fat and delectable. A very good complement to the standard menu. 

Keep it up, guys!

Brought a dozen of these glamour babes to the office this week.  They were gone in under and hour.  

Everyone wanted to know where they were from as they had not tasted such fresh, chewy, sweetly frosted doughnuts in an elephant's memory.  I only had a taste of two of them; the Blueberry and a Vanilla Frosted.  The former was mildly crisp on the outside, all fruit sweetness within.  The later had a fragile body, but a thickly poured sticky frosted coating.  Each was totally different than the other, as the frosted was soft with a delicious white coat, while the core was much like a well made glazed rounder that almost melts in your mouth.  The Blueberry was more cake-like, but totally infused with berryessence. 

Mary's is located within the Bristol Amish Market on Green Lane, just off Rt. 13. This market is also worth a review, as it is large, bright and cleaner than the one I often visit in Newtown, Pa.  

Only open Thursday - Saturday with the rest of the vendors there.  On Thursday morning around 7:30 am, there were few people in the building, and almost no line at Mary's.  Go later in the day, and you risk them being out of one or more of your favorites.  The Saturday mayhem may not be worth the trip. 

I think I found its sweet spot.

Trejo Restaurant on Swede Street, just down a bit from the Montgomery County Courthouse, is a very good casa Mexicana in the heart of Norristown. It has about ten tables and a small kitchen in the back corner. The menu has a full monte of breakfast, lunch and dinner options. The people working there appear to be family and are likely ownership. They are friendly, hospitable and seem proud of their establishment. 

It was late lunchtime, so a small Torta (sandwich) of thin sliced breaded beef caught my attention. When it arrived I knew that the adjective "small" was not really operative. This was a mega-sliced opus at least three inches thick, layered with beans, lettuce, avocado, tomato and spicy mayo, all held in a fresh roll with extra long toothpicks. The crisp fries were nice, but totally over the top unnecessary. 

The torta was great. Too wide for my jaws to clench, I partially deconstructed it by removing a couple of layers of the tasty res empanada, and rebooting it to a manageable dimension. From there, every bite was a delicious combination of all the ingredients exploding in my mouth. At $10 I felt bad that I couldn't finish it. Still, it was one of the better authentic Mexican plates I have enjoyed in long while. 

The good news is that my Norristown office is right down the street, so Trejo can become a regular stop when I am here for office meetings.

As Jersey delis go, Bob's Corner is a stud muffin!

It sits on the point (corner) of Delaware Avenue just west of Rt. 130, the first floor of a converted early 20th Century home.  Simple sign across the front steps, and small parking lot in back. There is barely room to turn around inside, but it is so well organized that it probably has everything you want for a solid take away breakfast and lunch.  The folks there are friendly and willing to chat while they do your bidding or take your cash. 

I stopped in for a quick caffeine jolt.  I wasn't hungry, but the aroma from the grill, and the sweet temptations from the muffin/donut display sure had my attention. Immediate mental note to come back with some room in the belly. The java was tasty and fresh, and the small cup a buck and a quarter.  Hard to beat.  

Roebling itself is a cool former company steel town that has had its own boom and bust cycle.  Now, it is a charming Delaware River burg that you have to have a reason to know about.  Mine? Mid morning cruise back to the office from Mt. Holly on an uber hot Friday in late July. 

Would you be rushing back to work?

Good things can happen even in the middle of a snowstorm, and I survived to write about it. 

The drive from Carlisle to Bucks was getting worse by the mile as snow and then sleet fell and made road conditions difficult.  With the speed limit reduced to 45 MPH, and my head beginning to pound, it was time for a break.  I was thinking comfort food, but when I drove into Malvern and my first choice (Pho) was closed on this Sunday, I found Dixie Picnic just around the corner, and seeing good Yelp reviews, I went in.  It might not be my normal comfy meal, but it certainly was someone's, and I was about to find out who's. 

The space was bright and cheerful even on a dank dark afternoon.  I arrived around 1:30, and they were closing at 2.  No sweat.  The owner welcomed me and told me to sit and relax.  He handed me the menu after explaining the general lay of the land with breakfasts, sandwiches, BBQ, and Box Lunches.  Everything done in house and from scratch.  Home brewed Iced Tea, too.  

I went with the Georgia BBQ Pork Sandwich on a fresh roll.  It came with a choice of a side dish - Pasta Pesto, thank you. While I waited, I listened to the oral history of this Southern family and the old photos on the walls took meaning and personality.  Lunch arrived.  

A huge heaping load of heavily sauced shredded pork that required a fork to consume because to pick up the sandwich was to risk a major lap spill.  It was that BIG. The first bite had me sucking in my breath as the deeply sweet and tangy mix attacked my tongue and olfactory center.  WOW!  This was going to required time and patience as I adjusted to its wonderful flavor.  It had just the right amount of vinegar to provide a sharp retort to the molasses-like thick sweetness.  It was soft and tender and an easy chew.  I found myself enjoying it immensely.

Meanwhile, the staff was beginning to close up, but I was assured that I could remain.  Good thing, because the other hot items were the Upcakes sitting seductively in the front display.  

These were upside down cupcakes covered on all sides in thick creamy icing.  The variety of flavors had their own menu and were seasonal.  Here, while the cake base was homemade and excellent, the real story was unabashedly the multicolored toppings.  I decided on the Blood Orange Icing on Devil's Food Cake.  

The icing was about a quarter inch think all around, save for the bottom (Actually, the top of this bottom's up creation). It was a soft cream, rather than a hard shell, and gave itself up freely.  While sweet, it was not overly so, and settled nicely on the tongue for a lasting taste sensation.  The chocolate cake was super moist and almost gooey.  I loved it. 

Whoever thought this one up deserves a place in the Cupcake Hall of Fame.  

Thanks to everyone associated with Dixie Picnic over the generations for your love of cooking and taking care of people.  

You all certainly took great care of me, and introduced me to new possibilities in comfort food. 

Gratitude and respect.

Philadelphia is known as a city of neighborhoods with good reason. There are many small enclaves with their own identity and distinct character with residents fiercely proud of where they come from. One of the best aspects of this street by street, hood by hood, awareness, especially from a Yelp perspective, is the presence of wonderful local shops, bars, and restaurants that maintain that sense of community every day of the week.  

Tate's Good Food Restaurant on Torresdale Avenue, in this corner of the city that shares the name, is one such iconic luncheonette that serves both the gastronomic needs of the area, and supports the people with quality breakfasts and lunches and a place to gather and commune together (shoot the sh*t). It is replete with folks who have lived nearby for generations, and frequent this small institution regularly.  Yes. Everyone knows your name. 

With this in mind, I stopped in for breakfast and took in the deep rooted atmosphere of this iconic establishment. I sat on a spinner along the counter, after checking out the tables on the opposite wall. A solo diner, I did not want to take up that much space, and after all, this was what a stool was for. Within seconds, I was called, "Babe," by one of the servers working the counter and floor, and, "Sweetie," by another, as she asked if I wanted coffee.  

She replied when I asked if she was talking to me - "Whatever works, right, Babe?" 
"That's cool. I just didn't want the other guys at the counter to get jealous."  
With that, one of those old dudes looked over at me with a stern gaze, and retorted, "She WAS talking to me, but, I don't mind if you thought it was you." 

Wink

 I knew I was in the heart of Philly. 

The menu was all about breakfast and lunch (they close around 2).  I went with the french toast, a side of corned beef hash and java. It arrived about 10 minutes later on an oval plate, with the hash on a second dish. I moved things around to get everything onto one before doctoring with butter and syrup.  

The meal was filling and satisfying. Six slices well egged and grilled. No real caramelization, but very tasty nonetheless. The hash was excellent. Deep savory flavor, a little crunchy. A great match for the sweeter fry bread.  The Bunn-O-Matic brewed a strong industrial joe which was replenished as often as requested. A small glass of real milk per my wish to avoid the heavier half & half. 

Tate's is another of those classic kitchens from a bygone era that have survived and even flourished.  It is as authentic today as it was in the last century.  It feels dated, but that is one of the two main reasons to come to a joint like this - For the wholesome hearty grub and to experience a living cultural museum.

If old fashioned roadside luncheonettes are your thing, then Delran Coffee Shop is where you want to have your next breakfast or lunch.  In the wilds of Delran (Delaware & Rancocas River/Creek merger nearby), this slophouse has been slinging hash and over-easy eggs, since your great grandfather was a youngun', and rode his bike with his buddies over for a greasy burger and fries.  There is a small counter for solo travelers like me, and a bunch of booths and tables for those who come with.  If this joint was any more authentic New Jersey, it would be one of Washington's stops during the Revolution in West Jersey. 

The place has a timeless quality.  Although well maintained, it feels its age, and the life stories of all who have dined here over the decades.  It is totally country in a cool, off the beaten path, Jersey way.  From my perch at the counter, I was on top of the grill, and watched as the cooks cracked their eggs on it, poured pancake batter, and dropped their presses on the bacon and burgers.  More important to me, I watched my short stack of French Toast go from bread bag to egg mix bowl to grill, with care and expertise. I saw it plated and brought to me by the short order dude, with small cup of butter, and counter rocket of syrup.  

When spread, melted and squirted, my breakfast looked great, and was caramelized on its edges, just the way I like.  The java was hot and free flowing, and the "honeys, and "dears," from the hard working server made me feel at home and appreciated. 

Between this place and Grannies' Attic Café up the way, I have stumbled on two exceptional breakfast joints that both garnered 5 stars for just being awesome interesting tasty spots to stop for the first meal of the day.  

And, they are both New Jersey thoroughbreds.

This is definitely as good as it gets in this part of Bucks County, PA, when it comes to Salvadoran and Mexican cuisine. Without a critical mass of Central Americans nor Mexicans in the area, the kitchen knows they are cooking primarily for gringos, and not their countrymen. They keep the joint clean, are bilingual, and pay close attention to the spice tolerances of their customers. They also have adapted the new policy of skipping the chips & salsa as a complementary snack while you wait for your ordered dishes. If you want those crunchies and sauces, you are going to have to order them, and add it to your bill. 

No problem. I don't need those extra calories, anyhow. 

I ordered beef flautas and fresh guava drink. They were both excellent. The flutes were oven-crunchy and full of well grilled and shredded beef, spices and cheese. The more I chewed, the more the flavor enhanced my palate. Delicious, with lettuce, onion and white cheese drizzled on top. The guava was cool and refreshing. Reminds me of apple juice, but more sweetness, and a hint of sour behind the bright sugar rush. 

Service was friendly and personable. Prices reasonable, coming in at just about $10 for my dinner, before tip. The room is a traditional colorful rendition of the restaurants found in the home countries. Even on a rainy evening, the dining room of La Corita Taco Shop shown bright.

La Cabana (The Cabin), certainly is not what the name suggests. It is far more than a cabin, but in actuality is a sparkling clean Latin American bakery, café and restaurant on Dayton Street in Trenton, NJ.  The casa recently opened and is totally renovated from the former occupant.  It is new from top to bottom.  The space is light and airy with a north facing wall of windows onto Dayton Street, and comfortable furniture and excellent service.  

I stopped in for breakfast after court today to check it out.  I was given a paper menu and invited to sit anywhere.  I took a table toward the rear where I could see everything that was going on.  I went with strong Columbian coffee, and the La Cabana Omelet, which arrived stuffed with chorizo, peppers, cheese, onion, potato and topped with fresh pico de gallo.  There was also a basket of fresh sesame seeded bread and butter provided.  

The meal was excellent.  Loved the egg dish.  It was steaming hot and melded together into a delectable hot mess.  Definitely a three egger. A few dashes of Tobasco and I was in business. The side of home fries were tender and nicely spiced, and really more than I could finish.  Nicholas stopped by several times to inquire as to my need for more coffee, and promptly took away the finished plates, while inviting me to remain as long as I wished.  Nice touch, as I was in no rush to leave this mellow, sunny place.  

I was lucky enough to meet the new owner, who was in a business meeting at a nearby table.  As I prepared to leave, the gentleman with whom she spoke approached me to ask about my impressions of the operation.  He was there to develop a marketing plan for them.  I gave him my honest appraisal, and had a short chat with his lovely client. Clearly, she is serious about the success of this enterprise.  If she maintains this level of quality and professionalism, it is all but assured. 

PS. Just a hint - Consider turning down the volume on the TV if no one appears to be watching it. Better soft music than talk shows, even in Spanish.

If you love simple and delicious Polish food, Pierogi Factory is singing your song.  

This tiny four table restaurant is in the Shops at Red Lion on Bustleton Avenue, Northeast Philly.  The menu focuses on the staples: Pierogies, Stuffed Cabbage, Potato Pancakes, Kielbasa and a few other goodies.  Service is casual and sincere.  

We ordered their Combo Dinners in order to sample as many of their dishes as possible.  Combo # 1 had two potato pancakes, 3 pierogis of choice (traditional potato and farmer's cheese), and 1 Golabki (stuffed cabbage), with a little container of sour cream ($9.95).  Every element was excellently prepared with taste as good as my grandmother used to make.  The other combo swapped out the potato pancakes for a nice length of smoked (grilled) kielbasa ($10.95).  Also, fantastic.  

I was full, but not stuffed, when we finished eating.  We shared a piece of apple cake ($3.00).  It was not as good as granny's, as it lacked the moisture, density and large apple slices she used to fatten up her grandchildren.  

Still, a very pleasant surprise on Bustleton. Will definitely visit here again.

If you know New York cheesecake, then you've already heard of Junior's.  Their restaurant in Times Square is a "must eat" destination when visiting the Big Apple.  Why?  Because since the passing of the dearly departed Ratner's in Manhattan, Junior's is left to carry the cheesecake torch.  It is super rich, creamy, sweet, and succulent.  It comes in a variety of flavors and sizes.  The wait for a table in any of their locations is legendary.  

But, now, there is no wait at all if you come to their factory and outlet store in Burlington, NJ.  You can walk around and see what they have available, and walk out with a stack of sweet heaven.  The prices start at only $2 for a 6 inch plain cake.  That is sinfully glorious, because money ceases to be an object in the decision to buy.  There is no splurge at that price.  

Nothing this good comes without a small reservation.  It is irrelevant to many, but the cakes in the outlet are slightly "irregular."  Some are lopsided; others have settlement cracks; a few have uneven swirls of strawberry or raspberry mixed in.  All these are rejected by quality control for the New York sites, but as a result, you can have a full cake here for less than the price of a single slice in the City.  

True. Self control becomes an issue when something this decadent is available in large quantities, variations, and at impossibly cheap prices.  The addicts were lined up outside the door waiting for it to open.  They all made a beeline to the free samples and stuffed face until all the small paper cups were gone.  While they were buzzing there, I found the Raspberry Swirl 8 incher I was looking for, and made for the cashier.  That baby went for $11, and will feed my family for more than a week on rations.

The anticipation of that first smooth creamy bite sends shivers up my spine. 

Who's the addict?

Richboro Coffee is a new java house in the Mallard Creek Shopping Center in Richboro, Pa. It is on the small side with about a half dozen tables.  The front of the room has a shiny copper roaster where all their Ethiopian, Kenyan and Costa Rican beans are prepared for brewing or sale. 

I sat down for a cup of their Ethiopian Sidamo, a muscular strong coffee that is great both straight up and with a little milk.  It is definitely a wake up call to the senses. The alternatives this day were a Kenya AA milder bean, or a Costa Rican decaf.  They can also be blended if desired. 

Service was friendly and informative.  Josh, the owner's son, worked the new digital register for my credit card purchase and seemed proud to be part of this enterprise.  Michelle, poured the Joe into a glass cup with room for milk, and offered to bring it to the table for me. Not handicapped, I did that myself, but appreciated the gesture. First sip alerted my tongue that a strong brew was on the way. By the time I was ready to depart, the caffeine had reached the brain, and I felt the welcome surge of focus and energy that only the freshest darker roast can provide. 

Exactly what I needed. 

Prices are reasonable for a custom roast/brew operation, at $2.25 for a regular cup; slightly more for extra volume. There were a few folks working at the tables while I was there, thus no shortage of seats for those who wanted to sit and sip at this time of day. 

Richboro Coffee joins other recently opened coffee houses in the area.  The coffee competes quite well with that from Newtown's Coffee Room and Yardley's Pretty Bird Café.  Each contributes in their own way to the upgrade of caffeine alternatives in the region, with Richboro seemingly with the best coffee, Newtown with the most comfort, and Yardley with the most variety on the menu. Fond of all of them.

Refills are a buck.

This Dairy Delite on Rt. 13 in Levittown is the twin of the ice cream stand on Woodbourne Road by the same name.  

It is housed in a mid-twentieth century style all glass summer enhancing structure that is iconic for those of us who remember going to such places as children.  As was the custom then, it is staffed by lovely high schoolers who bring their innocence and enthusiasm to the job of ice cream dispensers.  

When I got on the short line I saw the handmade sign for "Soft Peanut Butter," and allowed myself to be swayed by that suggestion.  No complaints, as the large cup of the dense, sweet, creamy, almost custard-like, soft serve was delicious to the last melted drop. 

Under $4. for all that pleasure.  Maybe it still is 1970 at Dairy Delite!

Sweet, creamy, cold. 

Orange Cream (twirl of vanilla and orange) tastes like childhood.

I just had one of the best cheesesteaks of my life!

Steve's Prince of Steaks has a shop on Route 1 in Langhorne, and although not far from my home, I had never been there, always preferring my local pizza shop for my grease fix.  Friday night, while I waited to pick up my son at a Magic tournament at OVM, I had some hunger and time to kill.  Steve's came to mind. 

I arrived about 30 minutes before closing.  There were only a few customers, and the staff was beginning to clean up.  I read the ordering directions a safe distance from the window, decided what I wanted and walked up to the young guy in the Steve T shirt and ballcap. The Cheesesteak wit Onions, Provolone and Roasted Peppers came out on the thin sheet of Steve paper.  When I attempted to pick it up with one hand I felt the heft of the sandwich and quickly put my other hand underneath to keep it from sliding off onto the floor. It was that heavy.  It was a work of art.  The peppers, onion and cheese glistened under the lights.  A small pool of oil began to collect once I placed it on the small stainless steel counter than runs around the shop. 

I went back to the fixin's bar to get some Banana Peppers to add more heat.  I sat down on the bar stool and looked at this creation.  I took a photo to commemorate the moment.  I really thought there was no way I could eat the whole thing. Then I took the first bite...

Heaven. I'm in Heaven...Yes, the song danced in my head.  The roll was lightly crusted and extremely fresh.  Great taste in its own right.  The blending of the ingredients on chewing was an intense explosive release of flavors, textures, spice and heat.  I lost all control.  I couldn't hold back.  I had an orgasm in my mouth before the second bite.  The sweetness of the onions soothed the heat from the peppers, but did not overcome them.  The provolone provided a subtle undertone that played well with the roll and sliced beef.  My eyes rolled into the back of my head and when they returned, the sandwich was completely ingested.  

The only thing I can say is, when can I go back for another? 

Suggestions:
1. Cash only. There is an ATM inside the shop, but why pay the extra charge?
2. To keep cost down, go with the Cheesesteak with American or Wiz, as the other cheeses are extra. 
3. Try the pepper fixin's bar before ordering extra peppers at the window.  There are plenty of choices there, and it is another buck or so to have them cooked with the steak.  
4. The fries are very good. If you care at all about your heart, try them straight, w/o the extra cheese.  It looks great all melted over the fries, but when it cools it is just a coagulated yellow mess.  That is how your heart sees it. 
5. Don't wait another day to have one.

South Philly is all about neighborhoods, and one of the best ways of bringing the community together is to have corner cafes in abundance that provide a warm safe place for people to congregate over excellent java and light comfort food. Whether studying or being contemplative, such atmosphere tends to bring to best out in us. So it is with Shot Tower Coffee.

Sitting on the southeast corner of S. 5th & Christian, the large plate glass windows filter the afternoon light into a mellow golden glow that quickly transforms the small room into a spiritual center whose ambiance is palpable. No wonder people come and hope to stay as long as possible; sometimes on their laptops, and often is simple chats or just meditating as they mindlessly stare out the windows to the street life on the other side of this gossamer screen. 

Not to mention that the bean life is also excellent, with friendly service folk who engage so well with customers. 

My chai latte was a large glass mug of well designed and prepared tea and milk that had great mellow taste and aroma. Likewise, the vanilla latte was bright with subtle vanilla flavor, and only needed a short shake of brownulated sugar to climb to the proper sweetness.  A sucker for lemon bars, theirs was wonderfully tart with crunchy base.  Loved it! 

Why is it called, "Shot Tower?"  Damned if I know, with its double meaning.  I'll leave that to the coffee historians.  All I know is that I'm glad to have finally stopped in and realized the pleasure of its charismatic grace.

Tikal Restaurant & Lounge is the successor to the venerable Rossi's Bar at the corner of Morris and Franklin in the Chambersburg section of Trenton, NJ.  At one time, Rossi's was considered to grill the best burgers in the city. When they moved out to Quakerbridge Road in Hamilton, there was a big void left behind.  

That emptiness has now been replaced with this well appointed  casa Guatemalteca. I stopped by for lunch recently and was impressed with the quality of the finished space.  The old square bar had been replaced with a wall unit with attractive wooden back bar.  There was new furniture in the barroom as well as the rear dining room.  New windows on the world were stenciled with the new name and its Mayan pyramid logo. Tikal is a famous historic site in northern Guatemala where the Mayan Civilization build a large city and temple complex before the arrival of Europeans, or even the Chinese before them.  

The menu is a bit of a fusion exercise, with a large national delicacies list, and a few Americano dishes like hamburgers and cheesesteaks with a definite Central American flair.  They also blend up excellent shakes and fresh fruit bedidas, using your choice of water or milk base.  I took a stool on a hightop in the barroom, and was served by bartender, Ana.  She had the right temperament for the job, and was friendly and prompt with menu, order taking and food delivery.  She was also patient as I worked my way through the menu looking for the right combination for lunch. She finally recommended the Tikal Wrap, with came with papas fritas.  I also ordered a mango smoothie as a washdown.  

The drink arrived in a tall frosted glass.  The mango mix with water was cool, semi-sweet, tasty and very refreshing.  The wrap was a monster, full of grilled chicken, lettuce, black beans, avocado, tomato and an interesting piquant sauce. I ate as much as I could, knowing that I would be skipping dinner that night.  It was excellent. The ample pile of fries was more than I could handle, but they tasted great with the spicy mayo that came in a bottle rocket on request. The app chips and homemade salsa were overkill, but I did dip a couple of the triangular chips, and thought the salsa nicely spiced. 

Tikal is one of the higher end Guatemalan houses in the Trenton area, and definitely worth a visit for lunch or dinner.  Prices are very reasonable.  I am particularly curious about their burgers, given the gloried history of the joint.  As I am not a fan of the new Rossi's, it would be ironic and poetic justice if the new Latin take on this American classic was better than the "new" original.  

Sometimes the city is the secret sauce that make for magical dishes.

We ordered the Soy and Sweet Chili Wings, as well as an attractive plate of Kimbap on a late Sunday afternoon in September. 

The house was dressed up in red and black lacquer, and KPOP blasted from the audio system.  Service was spotless.  We had the side room to ourselves.  So, while Soho may be SRO by night, if you want the great food without all the hustle, hassle and wait, try earlier in the day. 

From the look of most reviews, everyone already knows how awesome the Korean Fried Chicken (KFC) wings are. Double fried, and heavily dipped and basted, they arrive plump, crisp, loaded with flavor and plenty of juicy meat.  At a buck a wing, you are paying more than in the standard Buffalo wing joints, but there is really no comparison to the quality of the experience.  I was blown away. 

The Kimbap looked like sushi roll, but my server was adamant that they were very different.  Very good in their own right, but to my untrained palate, they were quite similar.  

Café Soho is on Cheltenham Avenue, in the town by that name.  It is not the most convenient place to transport to, except for the locals who discovered it years ago.  It is 30 minutes from mi casa in Bucks County, and likely even farther from Center City, Philly.  The travel adds to the excitement, so when it is finally seen on the near horizon, the heart quickens, and the saliva flows, in anticipation.  Walking in is entry to an alternate Korean universe.  Don't worry. Everyone is bilingual and very friendly.  The music is cool and hot (like the wings), but loud enough to interfere at times with conversation and appetite. 

Don't let that stop you.  The Wings are the Thing!

If excellently crafted chocolate wasn't sexy enough, calling it, "Naked," is completely over the top. 

Housed in a small shop in the Village @ Newtown Shopping Center, this outfit is a one trick pony of creamy, succulent candies that have your taste buds working overtime to cope with the sensory load. It all looks fantastic, and the samples at the counter make certain you try enough to bring you back for more. 

The one downside is the expense of self indulgence. The bonbons are $2.50 apiece, so a medium size box assortment hits $30 before you can take a breath. You really have to love someone (or yourself) to make that commitment. Well, I did and I do, so I won't be too disappointed in myself. 

Yes, my friends were duly impressed. The little balls of intense flavor wrapped in excessive opulent cacao were all that. With a good red wine chaser it was a near orgasmic experience. I watched as they bit their first bonbon and began to chew. Their eyes rolled to the back of their heads and a involuntary gasp escaped their lips. 

No doubt the best way to enjoy these delights from Naked Chocolate is to be naked yourself with someone you love. 

Soon.

China Gourmet is a very pleasant surprise if you, like me, love a traditional dim sum Chinese brunch every once and a while. 

Situated on St. Vincent Street in Northeast Philly between Brous Avenue and Roosevelt Boulevard in Mayfair, it is a large house in a developing Asian neighborhood that puts out trolley carts loaded with small dish treats both savory and sweet, at reasonable prices and with the expected hussle and flow that this dining style uniquely delivers. Admittedly, the aggressive nature of the cart ladies hawking their delicacies takes some getting used to. You have to be able to say "no" when you feel overwhelmed by the surrounding din. But, know that slowing down the onslaught is proper, and multiple opportunities will present themselves. Just take what you want in the moment and let the trolley women return when you are ready for more. 

The most important thing at China Gourmet is that they know from dim sum. There are dozens of choices and most of them are good to great. Shrimp and pork shumai, shrimp hargow, beef rice rolls w vinegar, fried stuffed buns, various dumplings, fish filled chili peppers, egg tarts and many others are well prepared and served hot or cold as appropriate. My bowl of congee was also decent with plenty of ground pork and fresh cut scallion on top. There is plenty more, but you get the picture. 

What's even better is the availability of FREE PARKING right in front of the restaurant, and the large Asian supermarket and Vietnamese kitchen right next door. The money saved is like getting a 25% discount off your check! Hard to beat! 

Now that we've experienced the fun and convenience of a strong dim sum morning with grocery shopping for dessert, Chinatown has lost some of its cultural luster for us (not completely). 

Gotta love it!

It was the Red Door in the middle of the building that I wanted, but it took three tries to discover it.  

The whole layout was confusing.  First, I walked into Levittown Lanes, the near-historic bowling alley at the east end.  I didn't want to bowl, but in my mind, the bar and bowling were in the same space, making for a lot of potential fun.  But, the man at the shoe counter, perhaps not understanding what I was looking for, sent me outside and to the last door on the right.  What did I know? 

I went into this plain wooden door without much of a sign, and found myself in a tiny dining area full of restaurant supplies and no customers.  To the right was the small takeout area with high half wall protecting the cashier and pizza ovens.  Ok. I ordered a Chicken Cheesesteak and inquired where the BAR was.  I was again sent outside and advised to take a left and enter the next door I came to.  Would my sandwich find me?  Sure. No problem.  

I followed directions, and finally entered the actual barroom.  It was of the dive bar genre.  Dim, smoky, rock & rolly, and full of fatigued workers who where here for a few brews on their way home after another tough day.  Def my kind of place.  I bellied up to see what the back bar looked like, and met Angela, the mistress of ceremonies and bartender fatale.  I explained the strange circumstance that brought me to her lair.  She laughed and said that I must really need a cold one.  The Pabst Blue Ribbon pint was $2 all night.  Solid unpretentious American suds, just like the Band Box.  

It went down so smooth and cool and tasted so comforting.  The guys around the bar accepted me as they saw the pint pour down my gullet without more than a swallow.  Thank you, Milwaukee.  They confirmed that I had found the best bar in Levittown - best food; best drinks; best prices. The Steak Sandy found me a few minutes later.  

It was large, with a cut transecting the midline.  The bread was nicely toasted and crisp.  It had a good yeasty flavor all by itself.  The shredded and grilled Chicken was mixed with Onion and Mushrooms, with American Cheese holding the innards together.  It was hot, steamy and delicious.  A squirt of Ketchup and I was in business.  Maybe it was the combination of Pabst, people and the deft touch of the kitchen hands, but that was the most enjoyable cheesesteak I had eaten in a long time (at least since my last visit to Steve's).  

Angela and I exchanged a few bar stories before I left.  Seemed we might know some of the same people in the biz.  I drove away thinking that of all the cool and curious old taverns in this part of the world, Band Box might be the best of breed.  

Next week. Same time. Same stool.

Still a great cheesesteak after several more visits over the past couple of years.  

The BIG STORY is the availability of a credit card processor that saves the time and expense of bringing enough cash or using the captive ATM.  

The sandwiches come to ten bucks with a drink, so it pays to be ready for the splurge.

Hinge Cafe on East Somerset Street in Port Richmond, Philly, is another great corner cafe in this part of the City of Brotherly Love. The atmosphere is urban casual, with wood upholstered furniture, step up side dining room, and lots of local artwork for sale on the walls. The menu is fairly traditional American fare. Breakfast and lunch are the focus. 

During the week there is ample street parking, although it may be necessary to walk a block or two. There is a small storm room entry at the corner front door, but once inside the full effect of this turn of the twentieth century retail space takes effect. It could just as easily be 1930 and 2018. I love that kind of time warping. 

Service is offered by friendly neighborhood women, who move efficiently through the shop loaded with coffee mugs, and large breakfast plates. The java was strong and refilled as needed. My request for milk rather than creamer was met with a small stainless pitcher of cow juice. My short stack french toast was well saturated with egg, vanilla and cinnamon mix and grilled up with a good caramelized surface. Tasted so good with melted butter and lots of syrup. 

The combination of old city streets, repurposed space and quality food made for a strong morning impression. Could have hung out a while longer with another mugga joe, but an appointment back in the 21st century beckoned. Still, Hinge Cafe is another of those exceptional cafes, luncheonettes, and pocket restaurants that make these historic hoods so interesting and worthy of repeat visits.

Great Made On Demand (MOD) Pizza that was actually much better than I expected from an assembly line restaurant concept. 

My Jasper pie was an 11" round crust loaded with spicy chicken sausage, mushrooms, red sauce and mozzarella with my addition of roasted garlic and balsamic fig finish that I dripped directly on to the pie when I got to my table at the back of the post industrially decorated shop.

 It was a thin crust that maintained crispness throughout. The taste was excellent with the three main ingredients able to project their flavors without the messy overlap of too many things going on to confuse the tastebuds. The garlic provided a touch of savory moodiness while the sweet/tart thick fig extract added a bit of gooey fun to the equation. It was darn good all thrown together. 

Then, I completely overindulged with their No Name Cake, which came wrapped in thin foil. It was in fact a giant house made Ring Ding, complete with light chocolate cake and a flush injection of butter cream hidden within. As a kid who grew up on Ring Dings and Yodels as snacks with milk, this was a giddy blast from the past that brought a not quiet sugar smile.

Mod Pizza moves to the top of the Newtown pizza scene. As a brand new business in town, I wish them great success.

On the same square as 1st Asian Supermarket in Mayfair, Philadelphia, in a corner brick two story, stands Marinucci's Deli. Those of you familiar, already know that it is a high volume higher quality Italian hoagie gold mine that creates stuffed sandwiches loaded with Dietz & Watson meats and cheeses, and a few signature pieces. Those of us who haven't been there before yesterday now know that this place is a legendary Philly landmark (30 years in this location) that turns out among the best Sammies in the city. 

I stopped in after a heavy afternoon of food shopping next door, and ordered two "small" 12" torpedos with Rare Roast Beef & Provolone and Roast Turkey & Swiss, both dressed with lettuce, tomato, mayo, oregano, hot & sweet peppers. Both To Go. 

Weighing in at about one pound each, we tore into the roast beef on the drive home. It was spectacular! The meat was fresh and tender, the provolone mildly tart and dry, that combined with all the accessories for a dynamic and delicious bite and chew. The best way to attack this zoftig big boy was with two hands and aggressive squeeze and stuff into the mouth, just like with a cheesesteak. We tag teamed it, my partner holding it in front of my face, while I grabbed with one hand and directed it into my mouth. It only worked at stoplights, but a couple of large bites did the trick. No fuss, no muss. Only a sesame seed from the roll jumping off the bread onto my lap before slipping to the floor. 

The Turkey & Swiss was just as good. Top flight ingredients and delightful eye opening taste. Both were good for two meals apiece, so we finished them later that evening with good brew and jalapeño chips. 

Marinucci's is one of those Philly joints that leave a lasting impression and a strong desire to return whenever in the neighborhood, which fortunately is about once a month. 

The corner of Brous and St. Vincent is a true destination for everyone seeking variety in their low budget culinary exploits. Vietnamese, Chinese, Boba and Marinucci's all in one square of Mayfair is a foodie's dream come true.

It's unanimous!

Cheese Dawgs is a great joint for Hot Dawgs, Grilled Cheese, and multiple combinations thereof.  Unassumingly sitting in a old Bustleton Pike strip, just south of Street Road, Rick Tyrrell has created a little bit of nostalgia for those of us who grew up loving hot dogs (frankfurters if you are from the New York area).  

While the décor is minimalist, it has everything needed for a legitimate happy meal.  With Bonanza playing on the TV, Rick introduced me to his shop and menu; recommending one of his newer items, the Grilled Cheese Dawg.  It is what is sounds like; a Grill Hot Dog wrapped inside a Grilled Cheese Sandwich.  All beef and well spiced (but not as much as Hebrew National garlicy meat tubes), it was an obvious "next step" in the evolution of two beloved American food groups. Symbiosis.  Tasty and fun.  With a side of Corn Chowder (perhaps, a little too thick, but still good), and a Stewart's Black Cherry Wishniak washdown, this was a fast lunch that had me smiling throughout.  

I hated to leave my childhood again, but knew it had to be.  To make it easier, Rick gave me a $5 off coupon for ordering my next meal online in advance of arrival, and made a last recommendation of his new Bacon Buttercup.  What's that?  Close your eyes...Imagine the best homemade Peanut Butter Cup - way better than Reece's...then add bacon.  Peanut Butter, Chocolate and Bacon.  

Stop drooling!

If that alone does not get you into your car and driving toward Bustleton, then go for the Dawgs and Grilled Cheese.  Either way, you can't lose.

Slowly, but surely, Bagel Train has become my primary bagel source.  While I still miss Bagel Junction in Newtown, the B Train has found a way into my heart and stomach with regularity.  My son and I stop in once a week before school to grab a breakfast of Onion Bagel, Butter and Swiss. He goes for Yoohoo, while I pour my first coffee of the day.  

The bite, texture and taste are exactly what we love (and kvell over).  This has become our routine. Bonding is a wonderful side dish with the bagels.  

Given the importance it has taken on in our lives, and the high quality and exceptional taste sensations generated, a bump to 5 Stars is overdue.

A+ for this authentic "Hole In The Wall" Mexican café, The Tropical Rooster.  

Right off South Broad Street at the corner of Park Avenue, El Gallo is a clean shop with about a dozen tables.  Sombreros line the walls, and Mexican soap operas play non-stop on the TV hanging from the ceiling.  The family owners are very friendly and bilingual, although I was the only Gringo having lunch.  I practiced my rusty Spanish, and received a few extra smiles for the effort.  

The menu offers a broad range of lunch and dinner options, and the kitchen is sufficiently visible to be able to see and hear the meals being made complete with the banter and laughter of the gifted husband and wife team.  

The Torta Al Pastor is a fat sandwich full of Grilled Pork, Onion, Pineapple, Cheese, Lettuce and a touch of Mayo, all stuffed into a oversized round roll.  It tasted great!  The Pork was lean with a touch of BBQ flavor, and the Pineapple added a distinct juicy undertone that really set off my taste buds. The mild Cheese hid beneath the two stars of the show, but provided a subtle ending to each bite.  This was large enough to be my dinner. I was not hungry again until morning. 

Jarritos Mandarin, a favorite carbonated beverage, accompanied the feast, and a side of well tanned Fries completed the ensemble.  Apparently, they also concoct some tropical smoothies. I noticed them too late, but next time I will unlock that secret. 

El Gallo Tropical is now on my short list for lunch, and will be a regular stop as one my favorite lunch spots now that I am working in the area.

La Stalla Market on Sycamore Street, Newtown, Pa, does a very good job creating a traditional Italian deli in the heart of this old town. Plenty of cheese wheels, dried sausage, breads, sweets and takeout meals for the asking; all in a small shop that smells as great as it looks. 

I was there to grab a sandwich for lunch. They have a long list of choices that can be wrapped, rolled or sliced-breaded. I went with their turkey BLT on a 12" crusty roll. It was huge. Stuffed with enough ingredients for two meals and smeared with aoili mayo that pulled the various tastes and textures together. The roll was excellent, with hard crusty exterior and well aerated sourdough flavor within. Definitely, best of breed master baker. Chomp and chew required strong jaw and teeth, and boy was it a worthwhile challenge. 

It was a great sandwich experience. 

Ate half, and rewrapped the remainder for later consumption (son devoured it as soon as I got home). $10 for two meals makes the price very reasonable. 

In a land full of mediocre pizza shops, it is so nice to have another vision of Italian cuisine so well represented.

If you can't get to DiBruno's in South Philly, you should give La Stalla Italian Market a visit for your Italian delicatessen and specialty requirements.  While not packing the huge inventory of cheeses, smoked meats, salads, and bakery goods of its distant cousin to the south, the Newtown store sure is a reasonable facsimile.  This new place looks and smells like 9th Street, and goes overboard when asked to create a sandwich or other takeaway meal.  

Their loaves are about the best Italian bread you can find anywhere in the area.  Certainly as good as Italian Peoples' Bakery and the dearly departed Barbero's in Chambersburg, Trenton, NJ.  It is so excellent that it can easily be enjoyed without anything more, or a little olive oil with black pepper, or a smear of butter.  But, if an incredible lunch is what you desire, just pick a few of your favorite sandwich ingredients, the size roll your want, and let the deli folk go to work.  You will receive an immense tower of wonderful meats, cheeses and accessories that will last at least two meals. If you prefer not to create your own combo, just select one of their house sammies.  You won't be disappointed. 

Newtown has been undergoing a renaissance for the past several years, with improved restaurants and boutiques merchandising everything from designer clothing, great smoothies, to tasty tidbits. La Stalla Italian Market joins the fun and is built to scratch that impossible culinary itch. 

Parking in the rear and on the street nearby.

Bagel Train remains my favorite bagel vendor in the area. 

Always a curiosity why people from Bagel City (born and raised there myself) think they know rounders better than anyone else, or that there is any uniformity among Big Apple bagels. There really isn't. I've had great ones on the Westside, and crappy ones in Soho. I've bitten into rock hard dense losers in Canarsie, and lovely light crunchers in Elmwood. 

So, don't listen to anyone who says they know what's best for anyone but themselves. If you love them, that's all that matters. Even if you never spent a day of your life in the City That Never Sleeps!

Past time for an updated review to reflect all the positive changes that this bagel emporium has gone through over the last few years. 

Biggest visible change was the expansion of their footprint and reorientation of the shop to permit side of building access which greatly enhances the size and feel of the space. Now Keystone is a for real cafe, with table and wall seating all around which gives a spaciousness to the operation.

Most important, they have built a bagel bakery right into the shop, with windows allowing customers to see the bagelmeisters at work. Not having to transport them from a more distant location means that the bagels are apex quality right from the oven to the bins. Nothing is lost in taste nor texture when the overall distance is about 20 feet. The difference in chewability is immediately apparent. Crisp firm outer skin and soft tender inner bagel, and full load of toppings (onion flakes for me), that stay affixed to the rounder, and don't fall off with normal handling. 

Service was excellent all around, with ordering at the counter and delivery to the table when done. Take out seemed just as smooth as I watched people come and go quickly. 

Keystone is planning an expansion into other shops and considering franchising the business. From what I saw and experienced on my last visit, they have a thoughtful plan and the means to execute. They listen to customers and are flexible enough to adapt to changing conditions. Personally, I would love to see them open up a little farther north in Bucks, and look into cross marketing with local coffee roasters where the best local Java and rounders were available in the same places and advertised together. 

The current situation is impressive, I suspect it will only get better from here! 

My candidate for Bucks Bagels of the Year!

Stopped by for breakfast this week, and was treated to excellent service, meal and ambiance all rolled into one sunny, cool autumnal morn. 

I couldn't ask for better weather for sitting at a deuce in the front window and having the sun through the glass warm my shoulders. Even with the diaphanous shades drawn to reduce the glare, the room was bright, white, and clearstory cheery. The dining area walls were all glass, letting in the beautiful bucolic 360 degree panoramas. I was warmly greeted and had hot strong Ellis Coffee on my table when I return from the WC.
